mainTopic.title: Chronic coronary artery disease
mainTopic.content_info: The materials for the topics can be found in the uploaded pdf files. The informations about the different topics listed on the ppt pages are sometimes limited and do not contain the necessary amount of content because of it's dense format, therefore it does not include every information but serves as a great foundation to form the questions and provide focus on core content, however additional background knowledge is needed to create quality revision quizzes.

quizzes.question: Identify the principal cellular event that initiates the development of coronary artery disease (CAD), leading to endothelial dysfunction and subsequent atherosclerotic processes.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Endothelial injury, marked by disruption of the endothelial cell layer and loss of its barrier function, is the primary cellular event initiating CAD, predisposing to inflammation and lipid accumulation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Smooth muscle cell migration from the media to the intima, characterized by phenotypic change and proliferation, is the primary cellular event in CAD initiation, causing endothelial denudation and platelet aggregation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Adventitial fibroblast activation, evidenced by increased collagen synthesis and extracellular matrix deposition, is the initiating cellular event in CAD, leading to medial thickening and reduced vascular compliance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Perivascular adipose tissue inflammation, characterized by macrophage infiltration and adipokine release, is the primary initiating cellular event in CAD, triggering endothelial dysfunction and systemic insulin resistance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Erythrocyte aggregation within the vasa vasorum, leading to microthrombosis and reduced adventitial oxygenation, is the initiating cellular event in CAD, causing endothelial apoptosis and impaired nitric oxide production.

quizzes.question: Determine the accurate chronological sequence of key cellular and molecular events during atherosclerotic plaque formation, from initial endothelial dysfunction to the development of a clinically significant lesion.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Endothelial Dysfunction -> Increased Permeability & Lipid Infiltration -> Monocyte Adhesion & Differentiation into Macrophages -> Foam Cell Formation -> Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation & Migration -> Extracellular Matrix Synthesis -> Plaque Progression & Complication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Increased Permeability & Lipid Infiltration -> Endothelial Dysfunction -> Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation & Migration -> Monocyte Adhesion & Differentiation into Macrophages -> Foam Cell Formation -> Extracellular Matrix Synthesis -> Plaque Progression & Complication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Monocyte Adhesion & Differentiation into Macrophages -> Endothelial Dysfunction -> Increased Permeability & Lipid Infiltration -> Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation & Migration -> Foam Cell Formation -> Extracellular Matrix Synthesis -> Plaque Progression & Complication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Endothelial Dysfunction -> Foam Cell Formation -> Increased Permeability & Lipid Infiltration -> Monocyte Adhesion & Differentiation into Macrophages -> Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation & Migration -> Extracellular Matrix Synthesis -> Plaque Progression & Complication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Extracellular Matrix Synthesis -> Endothelial Dysfunction -> Increased Permeability & Lipid Infiltration -> Monocyte Adhesion & Differentiation into Macrophages -> Foam Cell Formation -> Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation & Migration -> Plaque Progression & Complication.

quizzes.question: Explain the specific mechanism by which oxidized low-density lipoprotein (ox-LDL) contributes to the inflammatory processes in atherogenesis beyond simple lipid deposition within the arterial intima.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Ox-LDL induces endothelial cell activation through Toll-like receptors (TLR-4) and LOX-1, leading to increased expression of adhesion molecules (VCAM-1, ICAM-1), chemokines (MCP-1), and pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α), thus amplifying inflammation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Ox-LDL primarily enhances smooth muscle cell proliferation by directly stimulating growth factor receptors and increasing intracellular calcium influx, thereby promoting medial thickening and plaque stability through structural changes.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Ox-LDL acts as a potent inhibitor of macrophage phagocytosis, preventing the clearance of apoptotic cells and cellular debris within the plaque, which paradoxically reduces inflammation by limiting immune cell activation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Ox-LDL directly promotes nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) activation in endothelial cells, leading to increased nitric oxide production and vasodilation, thus counteracting vasoconstriction and reducing overall inflammation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Ox-LDL primarily functions as a substrate for intracellular lipid accumulation in fibroblasts, leading to extracellular matrix remodeling and fibrosis, which indirectly stabilizes the plaque by limiting lipid core expansion and rupture risk.

quizzes.question: Distinguish between stable angina pectoris and unstable angina based on their typical symptomatic presentation, underlying pathophysiological mechanisms, and immediate risk stratification for acute coronary syndromes (ACS).
quizzes.goodAnswer: Stable angina presents as predictable exertional chest discomfort, relieved by rest or nitrates, caused by fixed coronary obstruction; unstable angina features new onset, increasing frequency, or rest angina, often due to plaque disruption and thrombus, indicating high ACS risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Stable angina is characterized by nocturnal chest pain, unrelated to exertion, relieved by calcium channel blockers, due to vasospasm; unstable angina manifests as predictable exertional chest pain, relieved by beta-blockers, indicating moderate ACS risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Stable angina presents with prolonged chest pain lasting over 30 minutes, unresponsive to nitrates, due to complete coronary occlusion; unstable angina is characterized by brief episodes of chest discomfort, spontaneously resolving, indicating low ACS risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Stable angina is defined by chest pain radiating to the right arm, associated with ST-segment elevation, due to acute plaque rupture; unstable angina presents with atypical chest discomfort, relieved by antacids, indicating variable ACS risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Stable angina is characterized by chest pain aggravated by deep inspiration, reproducible on palpation, due to musculoskeletal origin; unstable angina presents with positional chest pain, relieved by leaning forward, indicating pericardial involvement and low ACS risk.

quizzes.question: Contrast the electrocardiographic (ECG) findings and cardiac biomarker profiles that differentiate Non-ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) from ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) within the clinical spectrum of acute coronary syndromes.
quizzes.goodAnswer: NSTEMI typically shows no ST-segment elevation, but may have ST-segment depression or T-wave inversions, with elevated cardiac troponin, indicating subtotal occlusion; STEMI presents with ST-segment elevation and elevated troponin, signifying total coronary artery occlusion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: NSTEMI is characterized by ST-segment elevation and elevated CK-MB, indicating transmural ischemia; STEMI shows ST-segment depression and normal troponin, suggesting non-occlusive vasospasm and minimal myocardial injury.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: NSTEMI is diagnosed by Q waves and elevated myoglobin, reflecting prior myocardial infarction; STEMI presents with T-wave flattening and normal CK-MB, indicating early ischemia without significant necrosis.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: NSTEMI typically shows PR interval prolongation and elevated BNP, suggesting heart failure; STEMI presents with QT interval shortening and normal myoglobin, indicating electrical instability and low ischemic risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: NSTEMI is characterized by normal ECG findings but elevated CRP, indicating systemic inflammation; STEMI shows diffuse ST-segment elevation across all leads and normal troponin, suggesting pericarditis rather than myocardial infarction.

quizzes.question: Elucidate the concept of 'silent myocardial ischemia', including its potential underlying mechanisms, epidemiological prevalence across diverse patient populations, and prognostic implications for long-term cardiovascular outcomes and tailored management approaches.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Silent ischemia refers to objective evidence of myocardial ischemia (e.g., ECG changes during stress test) without anginal symptoms, possibly due to altered pain perception or autonomic neuropathy, prevalent in diabetics and elderly, associated with increased cardiovascular risk, requiring aggressive risk factor modification.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Silent ischemia describes myocardial ischemia detectable only by cardiac MRI during vasodilator stress, absent in routine ECG or stress testing, related to microvascular dysfunction, prevalent in young women, with benign prognosis, requiring reassurance and lifestyle advice.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Silent ischemia signifies myocardial ischemia occurring solely during sleep, related to nocturnal vasospasm, prevalent in patients with sleep apnea and hypertension, with uncertain prognosis, requiring sleep study and blood pressure control.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Silent ischemia denotes myocardial ischemia with atypical symptoms like dyspnea or fatigue instead of chest pain, common in patients with heart failure and COPD, caused by global myocardial hypoperfusion, with poor prognosis, requiring advanced heart failure therapies.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Silent ischemia means ischemia with referred pain to epigastric region or back, mimicking gastrointestinal disorders, prevalent in obese individuals with GERD, caused by esophageal spasm, with uncertain cardiac prognosis, requiring gastrointestinal evaluation and symptom management.

subTopics.title: Concept of myocardioal oxygen supply and demand

quizzes.question: Describe the principal determinants of myocardial oxygen demand (MVO2), explaining how physiological and pathophysiological conditions modulate these factors to influence the delicate balance between oxygen supply and demand in the myocardium.
quizzes.goodAnswer: MVO2 is primarily determined by heart rate, ventricular wall stress (afterload and preload), and contractility; demand increases with exercise, hypertension, and hyperthyroidism, while reduced by beta-blockers, rest, and hypothermia, impacting ischemia risk based on supply adequacy.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: MVO2 is primarily determined by respiratory rate, tidal volume, and arterial oxygen saturation; demand increases with hyperventilation, hypoxia, and anemia, while reduced by supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilation, and polycythemia, directly affecting systemic oxygen delivery.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: MVO2 is primarily determined by renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and sodium excretion; demand increases with dehydration, renal artery stenosis, and diuretics, while reduced by fluid administration, ACE inhibitors, and renal replacement therapy, indirectly influencing cardiac workload.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: MVO2 is primarily determined by cerebral blood flow, intracranial pressure, and neuronal activity; demand increases with seizures, stroke, and fever, while reduced by sedation, hypothermia, and neuroprotective agents, unrelated to myocardial metabolic requirements.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: MVO2 is primarily determined by hepatic blood flow, bilirubin metabolism, and bile acid synthesis; demand increases with liver cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and hepatitis, while reduced by liver transplantation, diuretics, and ursodeoxycholic acid, indirectly affecting systemic hemodynamics.

quizzes.question: Explain the critical factors governing myocardial oxygen supply, with particular emphasis on the mechanisms of coronary blood flow regulation, myocardial oxygen extraction efficiency, and the impact of diastolic filling time and coronary artery anatomy.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Myocardial oxygen supply depends on coronary blood flow, oxygen extraction ratio, and hemoglobin concentration; coronary flow autoregulation maintains supply, primarily occurs during diastole, reduced by tachycardia, coronary stenosis, and anemia, limiting oxygen delivery.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Myocardial oxygen supply is determined by systemic blood pressure, cardiac output, and peripheral vascular resistance; supply increases with hypertension, hypervolemia, and vasoconstriction, primarily occurs during systole, enhanced by tachycardia and unaffected by coronary anatomy.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Myocardial oxygen supply is governed by pulmonary artery pressure, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and pulmonary vascular resistance; supply increases with pulmonary hypertension, fluid overload, and vasoconstriction, occurring equally during systole and diastole, independent of coronary flow.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Myocardial oxygen supply is determined by cerebral perfusion pressure, intracranial compliance, and cerebral metabolic rate; supply increases with increased intracranial pressure, hypercapnia, and neuronal hyperactivity, primarily occurring during systole, unrelated to coronary circulation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Myocardial oxygen supply is regulated by renal perfusion pressure, glomerular filtration rate, and renal tubular reabsorption; supply increases with renal artery dilation, increased extracellular volume, and reduced tubular reabsorption, occurring only during diastole, indirectly influenced by coronary flow.

quizzes.question: Discuss the concept of coronary autoregulation and its physiological significance in maintaining consistent myocardial blood flow across a range of perfusion pressures, detailing the underlying mechanisms and its limitations in the context of coronary artery disease.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Coronary autoregulation maintains stable myocardial blood flow despite changes in coronary perfusion pressure through myogenic response and metabolic vasodilation (adenosine, nitric oxide); impaired in CAD due to fixed stenoses and endothelial dysfunction, reducing coronary flow reserve and adaptability.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Coronary autoregulation refers to flow adjustment based on systemic vascular resistance, mediated by baroreceptor reflexes and hormonal systems (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system), primarily regulating systemic blood pressure and unrelated to local myocardial blood flow control.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Coronary autoregulation adjusts flow based on respiratory rate and depth, controlled by chemoreceptors and autonomic nervous system, mainly for systemic oxygenation and ventilation matching, with minimal direct impact on myocardial perfusion in healthy coronary arteries.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Coronary autoregulation modulates flow based on renal sodium and water excretion, regulated by aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH), primarily involved in fluid and electrolyte balance and indirectly affecting systemic hemodynamics, not directly myocardial flow.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Coronary autoregulation controls flow based on cerebral metabolic demand, achieved through neurovascular coupling and CO2 reactivity, crucial for brain function and neuronal oxygen supply, with no direct physiological role in coronary circulation regulation.

quizzes.question: Elaborate on the pathophysiological mechanisms differentiating myocardial stunning from hibernation in chronic ischemic syndromes, emphasizing their reversibility, distinct cellular adaptations, and clinical implications for functional cardiac recovery after revascularization.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Stunning is post-ischemic reversible contractile dysfunction due to oxidative stress and calcium overload after reperfusion, without necrosis; hibernation is chronic, reversible contractile dysfunction as adaptation to reduced flow, preserving viability; both improve with revascularization, but stunning recovers faster.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Stunning is irreversible myocardial necrosis following prolonged ischemia, resulting in scar tissue and permanent loss of function; hibernation is acute, transient contractile dysfunction caused by vasospasm, spontaneously resolving without intervention and unrelated to chronic ischemia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Stunning is chronic, progressive contractile dysfunction due to mitochondrial damage accumulating over time, leading to heart failure; hibernation is acute, reversible dysfunction due to electrolyte imbalance, rapidly corrected with electrolyte repletion and not associated with chronic ischemia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Stunning is immediate contractile dysfunction during ischemia, paradoxically improving with continued ischemia due to metabolic adaptation; hibernation is permanent loss of function due to apoptosis and irreversible cellular damage, not responsive to revascularization.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Stunning is delayed contractile dysfunction occurring weeks after ischemic event due to inflammatory remodeling and fibrosis; hibernation is intermittent dysfunction triggered by stress or exertion, spontaneously resolving with stress reduction and not indicative of chronic ischemia.

quizzes.question: Describe the processes of ischemic preconditioning and postconditioning, delineating their protective effects against myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury, and contrasting their timing of application, underlying cellular mechanisms, and clinical applicability.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Preconditioning is brief ischemia/reperfusion cycles before prolonged ischemia, activating protective pathways (KATP channels, adenosine receptors), reducing infarct size; postconditioning is similar cycles applied at reperfusion onset, limiting reperfusion injury by modulating intracellular calcium and oxidative stress.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Preconditioning involves prolonged ischemia followed by brief reperfusion to induce ischemic tolerance, paradoxically worsening infarct size; postconditioning applies brief ischemia before reperfusion to enhance reperfusion injury and prevent myocardial salvage.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Preconditioning involves administration of antioxidants before ischemia to directly scavenge free radicals and prevent oxidative stress, eliminating ischemia-reperfusion injury; postconditioning involves administering vasodilators after ischemia to improve coronary blood flow, enhancing reperfusion injury.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Preconditioning refers to long-term adaptive response to chronic ischemia with collateral vessel growth, providing sustained myocardial protection; postconditioning refers to acute adaptation to hypoxemia by increasing erythropoietin production, improving systemic oxygen delivery during reperfusion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Preconditioning involves surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque before ischemia to prevent coronary artery occlusion and ischemia-reperfusion injury; postconditioning involves implantation of a stent after ischemia to restore coronary blood flow, both unrelated to ischemia-reperfusion injury mechanisms.

quizzes.question: Explain the physiological role of coronary collateral circulation in chronic ischemic heart disease, including the mechanisms of collateral vessel development (angiogenesis versus arteriogenesis), their functional limitations in severe stenosis, and clinical implications for symptom modulation and long-term cardiovascular prognosis.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Collateral vessels develop in response to chronic ischemia via angiogenesis (new vessel sprouting) and arteriogenesis (vessel enlargement), providing alternative blood supply; often insufficient to fully compensate for severe stenosis but can reduce ischemia severity, modulate angina, and modestly improve prognosis in chronic CAD.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Collateral vessels are congenital bypass vessels present from birth, circumventing major coronary arteries, unrelated to ischemic stimuli; they provide complete protection against CAD, ensuring normal myocardial perfusion regardless of coronary stenosis severity, and are clinically insignificant.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Collateral vessels are iatrogenic vessels created surgically during coronary artery bypass grafting, improving blood flow in acute myocardial infarction; they are not naturally occurring and play no role in chronic ischemia or spontaneous symptom modulation in patients with chronic CAD.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Collateral vessels are venous channels draining ischemic myocardium, removing metabolic waste products and cellular debris, not supplying oxygenated blood; they paradoxically worsen ischemia by creating coronary steal phenomenon, detrimental in chronic CAD and worsening prognosis.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Collateral vessels are lymphatic vessels within the myocardium, draining interstitial fluid and inflammatory mediators, unrelated to coronary blood flow; they are primarily involved in immune response and have no significant impact on chronic ischemia symptom modulation or prognosis in CAD.

quizzes.question: Compare and contrast the diagnostic capabilities of exercise electrocardiography (ECG), myocardial perfusion scintigraphy (MPS), and coronary computed tomography angiography (CCTA) in the evaluation of individuals with suspected chronic coronary artery disease, considering their strengths, limitations, and clinical applications.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Exercise ECG detects ischemia during stress (ST depression), low sensitivity/specificity, readily available, initial test; MPS uses radioisotopes to assess perfusion defects at rest/stress, higher sensitivity for ischemia, functional assessment; CCTA visualizes coronary anatomy, detects stenosis, high negative predictive value, anatomical CAD assessment, useful in intermediate risk.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Exercise ECG directly visualizes coronary anatomy and quantifies stenosis severity with high sensitivity, gold standard for anatomical CAD assessment; MPS measures left ventricular ejection fraction at rest and stress, assessing global cardiac function independent of coronary ischemia; CCTA evaluates valvular heart disease and chamber dimensions, unrelated to coronary artery disease diagnosis.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Exercise ECG is the gold standard for detecting hibernating myocardium and assessing myocardial viability with high specificity, guiding revascularization decisions; MPS measures coronary flow velocity and microvascular resistance, assessing endothelial function and microvascular angina; CCTA quantifies coronary artery calcium score, predicting future cardiovascular events irrespective of current ischemia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Exercise ECG assesses cardiac autonomic nervous system function (heart rate variability) and predicts sudden cardiac death risk, low sensitivity for CAD detection; MPS detects valvular regurgitation severity and hemodynamic burden, assessing structural heart disease; CCTA visualizes pulmonary embolism and aortic dissection, unrelated to chronic coronary artery disease.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Exercise ECG measures myocardial oxygen consumption at peak exercise and quantifies ischemia severity with high specificity, guiding medical therapy; MPS detects ventricular arrhythmias during stress and assesses electrical instability, predicting arrhythmic risk; CCTA evaluates pericardial effusion volume and pericardial diseases, unrelated to coronary artery disease diagnosis or management.

quizzes.question: Outline the pharmacological treatment strategies for chronic stable angina pectoris, categorizing commonly used medications based on their primary mechanisms of action and their respective effects on myocardial oxygen supply, myocardial oxygen demand, and symptomatic relief.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Stable angina pharmacotherapy includes nitrates (venodilation, reduced preload/demand, symptom relief), beta-blockers (reduced heart rate/contractility, demand reduction, symptom control), calcium channel blockers (vasodilation, reduced afterload/demand, increased supply, symptom relief), and antiplatelet agents (prevent thrombosis, event prevention).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Stable angina pharmacotherapy includes diuretics (volume reduction, reduced preload/demand, symptom relief in heart failure), ACE inhibitors (vasoconstriction, increased afterload/demand, blood pressure control), digoxin (increased contractility, increased demand, heart failure management), and anticoagulants (prevent systemic embolism, stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Stable angina pharmacotherapy includes inotropes (increased contractility, increased demand, symptom relief in acute heart failure), vasopressors (vasoconstriction, increased afterload/demand, blood pressure support in shock), antiarrhythmics (suppress ventricular arrhythmias, rhythm control), and fibrinolytics (dissolve acute thrombi, acute myocardial infarction treatment).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Stable angina pharmacotherapy includes statins (lipid lowering, plaque stabilization, risk factor modification), antibiotics (reduce systemic inflammation, prevent infection), immunosuppressants (reduce autoimmune inflammation, manage autoimmune diseases), and analgesics (pain relief only, symptomatic management of non-cardiac chest pain).
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Stable angina pharmacotherapy includes bronchodilators (improve respiratory function, oxygenation in COPD), muscle relaxants (reduce chest wall pain, musculoskeletal conditions), proton pump inhibitors (reduce acid reflux symptoms, gastroesophageal reflux disease), and vitamin supplements (general health improvement, nutritional support unrelated to angina).

quizzes.question: Discuss the respective roles of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in the management of chronic coronary artery disease, considering critical factors such as disease severity and anatomical complexity, patient-specific comorbidities, and comparative long-term clinical outcomes.
quizzes.goodAnswer: PCI (stenting) is favored for less complex CAD (1-2 vessel disease, non-left main), lower invasiveness, faster recovery, effective symptom relief; CABG (surgical bypass) is preferred for complex CAD (multivessel disease, left main stenosis), better for diabetics and complex anatomy, potentially superior long-term outcomes in severe CAD, but higher initial procedural risk and longer recovery.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: PCI (stenting) is exclusively indicated for left main coronary artery stenosis due to higher efficacy in severe CAD and superior long-term patency rates compared to CABG; CABG (surgical bypass) is reserved for single vessel disease in young, low-risk patients seeking cosmetic advantages and shorter hospital stays.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: PCI (stenting) is contraindicated in diabetic patients and those with multivessel disease due to significantly higher risks of restenosis and stent thrombosis; CABG (surgical bypass) is the primary and universally recommended treatment for all forms of coronary artery disease, regardless of severity or anatomical complexity, offering universally superior outcomes.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: PCI (stenting) has no role in chronic stable angina management and is primarily used for acute coronary syndromes to restore immediate flow; CABG (surgical bypass) is used for primary prevention of CAD in asymptomatic individuals with multiple risk factors, providing excellent long-term protection against future cardiac events.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: PCI (stenting) is not a revascularization strategy but solely a diagnostic tool to assess coronary artery stenosis severity; CABG (surgical bypass) is exclusively used for peripheral artery disease to improve limb perfusion and has no application in the management of coronary artery disease or angina symptoms.
